scenario:
Lowe's Companies, Stanley Black & Decker, and Kohl's Corp stocks have seen significant gains following a 90-day pause on post-April 2 tariffs between the US and China. The US agreed to reduce the tariff rate on imported Chinese goods to 30% and on exported US goods to 10%. This decision aims to "decouple" the US economy from China for strategic necessities, but not entirely. 

The US Treasury Secretary stated that the goal is not a generalized decoupling from China, but rather a decoupling for strategic necessities. The administration will ensure that certain Chinese goods are made in the US, not imported. 

Lowe's imports 40% of its goods, with a significant portion from China. Stanley Black & Decker imports $1 billion in goods annually from China and $1.3 billion from Mexico. Kohl's imports about 20% of its wares from China. 

Despite the temporary truce, the stocks remain affected by the progress of China-US tariff negotiations and global tariffs negotiations. The companies will still be impacted by tariff rates from their new sources. Investors should remain cautious and continue to monitor the situation. 

Key financial information: 
- Lowe's Companies: up 4.6%
- Stanley Black & Decker: up 14.6%
- Kohl's Corp: up 12.4%
- Tariff rate on imported Chinese goods: 30%
- Tariff rate on exported US goods: 10%
- Percentage of goods imported by Lowe's: 40%
- Percentage of goods imported by Stanley Black & Decker from China: 15%
- Percentage of goods imported by Kohl's from China: 20%
response:
{
  "id": "T0",
  "title": "90-day pause on post-April 2 tariffs (Partial decoupling strategy)",
  "description": "US and China agree to a 90-day suspension of additional tariffs and partial reductions (30% on US imports from China, 10% on Chinese imports of US goods). The deal aims to decouple only for ‘strategic necessities’ while maintaining some level of bilateral trade.",
  "children": [
    {
      "id": "T1A",
      "title": "Path A: Gradual Progress Towards a Targeted Deal",
      "date_range": "Next 2–4 months",
      "description": "Negotiations continue with modest breakthroughs; focus remains on critical industries. The US enforces stricter domestic production for a subset of goods, while letting market forces handle non-strategic items.",
      "children": [
        {
          "id": "T1A.1",
          "title": "Supply Chain Reconfiguration Accelerates",
          "date_range": "Month 1–3",
          "description": "Under the partial decoupling framework, US companies in strategic sectors (e.g., hardware, high-tech components) ramp up their efforts to source outside China. Lowe’s, Stanley Black & Decker, and Kohl’s begin diversifying into Mexico, Vietnam, and other lower-tariff countries.",
          "children": [
            {
              "id": "T2A.1",
              "title": "Corporate Investment Shifts",
              "date_range": "Month 3–6",
              "description": "• Lowe’s invests $200M in new supply contracts in Southeast Asia. \
• Stanley Black & Decker increases production at US plants, leveraging possible tax incentives for reshoring strategic goods. \
• Kohl’s diversifies apparel sourcing, partially hedging against future tariff hikes. \
Investors look for supply chain management tech equities as winners.",
              "children": [
                {
                  "id": "T3A.1",
                  "title": "Market Stability and Cautious Optimism",
                  "date_range": "Quarter 2–Quarter 3",
                  "description": "• Retailers see margin pressures ease slightly as alternative supply lines develop. \
• Consumer sentiment improves, reflecting predictability in trade policies. \
• Short-term upside for logistic and freight companies handling rerouted supply chains. \
Portfolio consideration: moderate long positions in domestic manufacturing plays and third-party logistics firms."
                }
              ]
            }
          ]
        },
        {
          "id": "T1A.2",
          "title": "Limited Tariff Relief Spurs Moderately Positive Outlook",
          "date_range": "Month 4–6",
          "description": "With partial tariff relief, consumer spending picks up. However, the administration remains vigilant, reiterating the strategic decoupling message for key technologies. Markets remain watchful for political signals.",
          "children": [
            {
              "id": "T2A.2",
              "title": "Momentum Towards Sector-Specific Deals",
              "date_range": "Quarter 3–Quarter 4",
              "description": "• US–China finalize mini-deals on non-sensitive sectors (e.g., basic consumer goods). \
• Tariffs on certain segments drop further (e.g., from 30% to 25%), giving retailers like Kohl’s a mild cost reduction. \
• Strategically sensitive items remain at or near 30%, encouraging further US-based production. \
Investment view: accumulate shares of home improvement and retail stocks benefiting from incremental tariff reductions."
            }
          ]
        }
      ]
    },
    {
      "id": "T1B",
      "title": "Path B: Stalemate and Increased Pressure",
      "date_range": "Next 2–4 months",
      "description": "Negotiations stall as both sides struggle to define ‘strategic necessities.’ China becomes wary of selective decoupling, while the US administration signals readiness to restore higher tariffs if talks falter.",
      "children": [
        {
          "id": "T1B.1",
          "title": "Renewed Tariff Threats",
          "date_range": "Month 2–3",
          "description": "• US warns tariffs could return to 40% on Chinese imports if China fails to meet manufacturing relocation targets. \
• Retailers fear supply chain disruptions; share prices turn volatile. \
• Stanley Black & Decker accelerates cross-border expansions in Mexico to mitigate China risk. \
Investor action: consider short-term hedges for retailers with high China exposure.",
          "children": [
            {
              "id": "T2B.1",
              "title": "Backlash and Political Scrutiny",
              "date_range": "Month 3–5",
              "description": "• US retailers lobby Congress for tariff relief, citing inflationary pressures on consumer goods. \
• Domestic manufacturing groups push for broader protectionist measures, seeing partial decoupling as insufficient. \
• Growing consumer reluctance to absorb price hikes leads to lower retail earnings forecasts. \
Markets may see rotation from retail into stable consumer staples and domestic industrials."
            }
          ]
        },
        {
          "id": "T1B.2",
          "title": "China Retaliates on Key US Exports",
          "date_range": "Month 3–5",
          "description": "• Beijing imposes or threatens new 15–20% tariffs on US-made machinery and certain agricultural goods in response. \
• The US signals readiness to impose further ad hoc restrictions on advanced tech exports. \
• Tensions drive investor anxiety; volatility spikes in equity and currency markets.",
          "children": [
            {
              "id": "T2B.2",
              "title": "Global Supply Chain Disruptions Intensify",
              "date_range": "Quarter 2–Quarter 3",
              "description": "• Multinationals rush to relocate production; capacity constraints raise short-term costs. \
• Retailers reliant on just-in-time inventory, like Kohl’s, face stockouts and pass on higher prices to consumers. \
• Potential equity market dip in consumer discretionary stocks. \
Possible trade: short near-term cyclical consumer stocks while going long domestic manufacturing and automation providers."
            }
          ]
        }
      ]
    },
    {
      "id": "T1C",
      "title": "Path C: Surprise Breakthrough and Broad De-Escalation",
      "date_range": "Next 2–4 months",
      "description": "Unexpectedly, both sides pivot to reduce tensions more substantially, citing global economic headwinds and mutual desire for stability. Tariffs are significantly lowered across multiple categories.",
      "children": [
        {
          "id": "T1C.1",
          "title": "Rapid Tariff Rollback",
          "date_range": "Month 2–4",
          "description": "• US–China reach an extended agreement to reduce tariffs to 15% on imports and 5% on exports, excluding identified ‘ultra-strategic’ categories (some advanced tech). \
• Retailers like Lowe’s, Stanley Black & Decker, and Kohl’s experience margin relief as Chinese import costs fall. \
• Consumers see price cuts across home improvement tools, appliances, and apparel.",
          "children": [
            {
              "id": "T2C.1",
              "title": "Stock Rally and Emerging Growth",
              "date_range": "Quarter 2–Quarter 3",
              "description": "• Equity markets surge, led by retail and manufacturing sectors. \
• Lowe’s invests in supply chain digitalization to maximize cost efficiencies. \
• Stanley Black & Decker shifts some planned US production expansions into strategic R&D to capture new growth. \
Opportunity: go long on retailers and consumer discretionary stocks poised for margin expansion."
            }
          ]
        },
        {
          "id": "T1C.2",
          "title": "Selective Reshoring but Improved US-China Relations",
          "date_range": "Month 4–6",
          "description": "• The US retains partial decoupling measures on high-tech hardware, encouraging domestic chip and robotics investments. \
• China opens more consumer sectors to US businesses; Kohl’s explores direct e-commerce channels in China. \
• Corporate sentiment improves globally; potential for modest global GDP uptick by next year. \
Portfolio positioning: maintain cyclical retail positions, consider strategic growth in industrial automation beneficiaries."
        }
      ]
    }
  ]
}
